title: Combat-net radio
text:
In <a href="telecommunication">telecommunication</a>, a combat-net radio (CNR) is a <a href="radio">radio</a> operating in a <a href="telecommunications%20network">network</a> that (a) provides a <a href="duplex%20%28telecommunications%29">half-duplex</a> <a href="Telecommunication%20circuit">circuit</a> and (b) uses either a single <a href="radio%20frequency">radio frequency</a> or a discrete <a href="Set%20%28mathematics%29">set</a> of radio frequencies when in a <a href="frequency%20hopping">frequency hopping</a> <a href="Transverse%20mode">mode</a>.
CNRs are primarily used for <a href="push-to-talk">push-to-talk</a>-operated radio nets for <a href="Command%20and%20Control%20%28Military%29">command and control</a> of <a href="combat">combat</a>, combat support, and <a href="combat%20service%20support">combat service support</a> operations among <a href="military">military</a> ground, sea, and air forces.
In the United States, two military standards govern the use of combat net radios and the host applications that communicate over the network: <a href="MIL-STD">MIL-STD</a>-188-220 and MIL-STD-2045-47001. In addition to IETF RFCs governing UDP, TCP, and IPv4/IPv6, all seven layers of the <a href="OSI%20model">OSI communications architecture</a> are addressed. MIL-STD-2045-47001 covers layer 7 (<a href="Application%20Layer">application</a>), while MIL-STD-188-220 covers layers 1 through 3 (<a href="Physical%20layer">physical</a>, <a href="Data%20link%20layer">data link</a>, and <a href="Network%20layer">network</a>).
